Жить [...] быть [...] жить, быть и видеть [...] жить-быть [...] жить-быть [...] It is also resonant with the list of verbs that comes as an epigraph in "A School for Fools": 
Гнать, держать, бежать, обидеть, слышать, видеть, и вертеть, и дышать, и ненавидеть, и зависеть, и терпеть.

The narration in the chapters concerning Yakov are characterized by their more poetic style. This narrator, for instance, frequently uses infinitives, which evoke the eternal quality and endless time of the novel's setting.

highlighted:
Метель, о ком многие думали еще через я, тогда как 
особым указом его давно передали Зайцу, на кого и безухое оно 
столь походило, а несвойственное и ненужное Зайцу е передали метели, — она расходилась, разыгрывалась, делаясь неугомонной и неумолимой.
text:
Метель (blizzard) was previously spelled мятель, as заяц (hare) was once spelled заец. In this section, as Martina Napolitano suggests, Sokolov plays with "the close pronunciation of certain unaccented vowels in Russian, which often gives rise to misspelling – я, е, й" (Napolitano, “Studyin This Volapuke” 289). Letters are transferred from word/concept to word/concept. Here, Sokolov also alludes to the story of how Alexander Pushkin, the father of Russian letters, encountered a hare on the road while on his way to support the Decembrist Revolt and took it as a bad omen.Bravo! This is fascinating!I've proposed a different explanation, maybe we can think about it:

the pairs metel'/mjatel' and zajac/zaec appear in connection with different linguistic phaenomena: 
metel'/mjatel' reflects an alternative use of the vowel linked to the spelling instability still dominant in the 19th century and on which a great many authors, from Pushkin to Blok, played, also because of the possibility to reflect a different semantic intention (see Vasil'ev 2008 - VASIL’EV 2008: Vasil’ev S., “Metel’” ili “Mjatel’”? O zaglavii povesti A. S. Puškina, in «Russkaja reč’» 6 (2008), pp. 8-11, http://russkayarech.ru/files/issues/2008/6/02-vasiljev.pdf.). Metel', in fact, has its root in the verb mesti, to sweep, while that of mjatel' is to be found in the verb mjastis', to provoke smjatenie (confusion, disarray); in authors who make conscious and calibrated use of the two variants, it is precisely with this condition that the use of mjatel' is to be associated, as its strong expressive connotation prevails over the simple and objective identification of the natural phenomenon. 
2. zajac-zaec refers to the different outcome of the nasalised -e- of Late Proto-Slavic which becomes, in East Slavonic, -ja- and, in South Slavonic, -e-: zajac is, therefore, the more purely Russian form, while zaec reflects Slavonic-ecclesiastic outcomes and is therefore readable as a learned marker. 
The two pairs, which are never clearly defined as the object of discourse but whose (co)existence is taken for granted, are placed in correlation because Ilya imagines that mjatel' has surrendered the -ja-, useless to her, to zaec, who would have preferred it by virtue of the relatability of the form of the -ja-/я to a stylised, albeit earless, rabbit. In return, he would have ceded his -e-: the two forms of the modern standard, zajac and metel', would thus have been defined by their internal agreement, with extremely poetic and synaesthetic characters due to the decisive role played by the graphemes themselves.

This also recalls the ancient russian setting of the novel, whose plot seems to take place at the same time a long time ago and in the years after WWII

text: Idiomatic phrase: переливать из пустого в порожнее (to chase one's own tail, to mill the wind, literally: to pour from an empty (container) to the empty (one). Here, the phrase suggests the senseless of the engineer's speech. The phrase is also an echo of a key idea of Yakov's (the Binging Hunter) cited by Ilya in chapter 8: "Не превратно ль, доказывает, вино сего года в старую бочку лить" (206).

Orekhovo-Zuyevo is an industrial city in the Moscow Oblast, located approximately 53 miles east of Moscow. The city was originally three villages—Orekhovo, Zuevo, and Nikolskoye—that merged in 1917. Here, Sokolov splits the name into two.

text: A striking example of Sokolov's transformations. Here, the chaotic noise of the pavilion's environs is likened to raggedy clothing, which, in turn, is called to take flight, to move and hang on clotheslines and, finally, transform into birds. From the low rises up something beautiful (the pastel colors, the birds), and different senses are activated as the sound transforms into physical beings.

The chapters concerning Yakov place a great deal of attention on colors. This is no surprise given how they frequently imagine scenes as if they are being painted before the reader's eyes or observed in a gallery.

An encoded reference to Luke 8:17: "Ибо нет ничего тайного, что не сделалось бы явным, ни сокровенного, что не сделалось бы известным и не обнаружилось бы" ("For there is nothing hidden that will not be disclosed, and nothing concealed that will not be known or brought out into the open"). Much in the novel, for instance, the sequence of crimes that lead to Ilya's death, is not revealed until close to its end.

text: A Circassian horseman in Mikhail Lermontov's novel *Hero of Our Time* (1940). In the chapter "Bela", the titular character's brother, Azamat, offers his sister in exchange for Kazbich's famed horse, Karagez. When he declines, Azamat conspires with the novel's protagonist, Grigory Pechorin, to steal the horse, resulting in Bela's eventual murder at the hands of Kazbich.

In the chapter "Bela", the titular character's brother, Azamat, offers his sister in exchange for Kazbich's famed horse, Karagez, whom he praises in this way. text: To say, a valuable painting depicting the result of a hunting battue

A central motif in the novel, this phrase alludes to *The Hunters in the Snow*, a 1565 painting by Pieter Bruegel the Elder. The setting and action of this image recurs throughout *Between Dog and Wolf* (e.g., R202–203/E93–95), as they come to life in the text. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d8/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_Hunters_in_the_Snow_%28Winter%29_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)

text: The narrator here suggests that it's the circumstances determine a thing's appearance, character, and so on, rather than the other way around. In other words, different contexts will generate different phenomena, much as the characters and settings in the novel shift depending on how their parts and configurations have been arranged around them. In short, a suggestion that art is self-defining.

text: Archaism: eyes

Word used in set expressions (зги нет, ни зги, зги не видать, ни зги не видать, ни зги не видно: что бы то ни было, Слепой слепого водит, а оба зги не видят) meaning that nothing is visible. According to Dal''s dictionary, зга means "темь, потемки, темнота" (darkness). This definition presents a complication, as the phrase "ни зги не видать" would come to mean "no darkness is visible" (so dark that even the darkness is obscured?. However, Dal' also proposes that the word зга originated from "стьга" (path, road), which would make more logical sense in the various expressions that use зга. According to yet another version, Sokolov's "favorite," a зга is a ring on a yoke, which a driver couldn't see in the dark (Sokolov, "Bol'shoe pis'mo" 126).

text: Dated: to urge, admonish, exhort

highlighted: икоту перейти на безропотных страстотерпцев Федота и Якова
text: A reference to the saying "Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого" (Hiccups, hiccups, go to Fedot, from Fedot to Yakov, from Yakov to everyone). This proverb derives from the folk belief that hiccups (a disease or demonic invasion) could be passed from one person to another. This hiccup (and the barrel further below) develops also the recurrent drinking theme.

Latin: Life without freedom is nothing.

Latin: To live is to fight. A borrowing from Seneca the Younger, the Roman Stoic philosopher, statesman, dramatist, from his [*Moral Letters to Lucilius* (96.5)](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Moral_letters_to_Lucilius/Letter_96#:~:text=I%20shall%20not%20endure%20myself,this%20is%20a%20common%20thing.).

Yakov. A reference to the novel's [epigraph](https://digitalscholarship.brynmawr.edu/dog/texts/00_ru/) from Boris Pasternak's *Doctor Zhivago*: "Молодой человек был охотник."It somehow reminds (me) of Esenin's famous (last) words too: "В этой жизни умирать не ново, / Но и жить, конечно, не новей".
